content:
The Government Management Reform Act of 1994 includes titles on Limitation on Pay, Human Resource Management, Streamlining Management Control, and Financial Management. It establishes limitations on annual pay adjustments and addresses issues related to SES annual leave accumulation, efficiency in reporting to Congress, electronic payments, franchise fund pilot programs, simplification of management reporting process, and annual financial reports. Effective as of December 31, 1994, amendments were made to the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946 and title 3, United States Code. The amendments set limitations on percentage adjustments in rates of pay, ensuring they do not exceed adjustments under section 5303 of title 5, United States Code. Additionally, changes were made to the structure and effectiveness of certain sections within title 3. The amendments to title 5, United States Code, set limitations on percentage adjustments in rates of pay, ensuring they do not exceed adjustments under section 5303 of title 5. The amendments to title 28, United States Code, set limitations on percentage adjustments in rates of pay, ensuring they do not exceed adjustments under section 5303 of title 5. Title II - Human Resource Management

SEC. 201 - SES Annual Leave Accumulation. Effective on the first day of the first applicable pay period after the enactment of this Act, subsection (f) of section 6304 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow for increased annual leave accumulation for individuals in specified executive positions. On the effective date of the amendment, employees with excess annual leave can retain it and it will be subject to reduction as specified in section 6304. TITLE III--STREAMLINING MANAGEMENT CONTROL

SEC. 301. AUTHORITY TO INCREASE EFFICIENCY IN REPORTING TO CONGRESS. The purpose of this title is to improve the efficiency of executive branch performance in implementing statutory requirements for reports to Congress and committees by eliminating duplicative or obsolete reporting requirements and adjusting deadlines for more efficient workload distribution. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget has the authority to recommend consolidation, elimination, or adjustments in frequency and due dates of statutorily required reports to Congress, providing individualized reasons for each recommendation. The Director shall provide specific recommendations for consolidation, elimination, or adjustment of report requirements, consistent with the purpose of improving efficiency. Consultation with congressional committees is required before publishing recommendations. TITLE IV--FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT

SEC. 401. SHORT TITLE.

    This title may be cited as the ``Federal Financial Management Act 
of 1994''.

SEC. 402. ELECTRONIC PAYMENTS.

    Section 3332 of title 31, United States Code, is 
amended to require direct deposit. Federal wage, salary, and retirement payments must be made via electronic funds transfer, unless waived by the agency head upon written request by the recipient. Recipients need to designate financial institutions for payment receipt. The Secretary of the Treasury may waive the requirements for federal wage, salary, or retirement payments for groups of recipients upon request by the agency head. This applies to recipients who start receiving payments on or after January 1, 1995. The Secretary of the Treasury may waive payment requirements for federal recipients starting on or after January 1, 1995. Payments credited by designated financial institutions serve as full acquittance to the United States. Chapter 33 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to require direct deposit. SEC. 403. FRANCHISE FUND PILOT PROGRAMS. Establishment of franchise funds on a pilot program basis in six executive agencies authorized by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. These funds can provide common administrative support services more efficiently through acquiring capital equipment and automated data processing. Authorized funds for agencies to acquire necessary equipment and systems on a competitive basis. Appropriations to franchise funds for agency purposes, with fees set to cover service costs. Existing inventories to be included. The fund allows for the transfer of existing inventories, equipment, and assets. A report on pilot programs must be submitted within 6 months after fiscal year 1997, detailing financial and program performance results, along with recommendations for fund structure, funding mechanism, competition promotion, and potential application extension. The provision allows for the extension of franchise funds to other Federal agencies. Nothing in this section relieves agencies of their duties under procurement laws. The provisions of this section will expire on October 1, 1999. SEC. 404. SIMPLIFICATION OF MANAGEMENT REPORTING PROCESS. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget may adjust the frequency and due dates of statutorily required reports to improve efficiency in implementing financial management reporting to Congress. This authority applies only to reports of agencies to the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget can adjust the frequency and due dates of required reports to improve efficiency in financial management reporting to Congress. This adjustment applies to reports between January 1, 1995, and September 30, 1997, after consultation with relevant committees and notification to Congress by February 8 of each fiscal year. SEC. 405. ANNUAL FINANCIAL REPORTS. Amends Section 3515 of title 31, United States Code to require financial statements of agencies. Executive agencies must submit audited financial statements to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget annually, covering all accounts and activities. The statements should reflect the financial position and results of operations of the agency components identified by the Director. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget prescribes the form and content of financial statements for executive agencies. Waivers may be granted for certain fiscal years. Executive agencies must submit audited financial statements annually by March 1, covering all accounts and activities. The head of each executive agency must submit a financial statement to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget by March 31 for the preceding fiscal year, covering revolving funds, trust funds, and commercial functions. Commercial functions include real estate transactions, insurance, loans, and credit programs. The head of each executive agency must submit a financial statement to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget by March 31 for the preceding fiscal year, covering revolving funds, trust funds, and commercial functions, which involve services or things for which a fee is imposed. Audits by agencies must be conducted in accordance with government auditing standards. The Secretary of the Treasury, in coordination with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, must annually prepare and submit an audited financial statement to the President and Congress by March 31 for the preceding fiscal year, covering all accounts and activities of the executive branch of the United States Government. The financial statement should reflect the financial position, assets, liabilities, and operations of the executive branch. The Comptroller General of the United States shall audit the financial statement required by this section, prepared in accordance with the form and content requirements set forth by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget.
